This insightful new issue has various articles from the themes of body aesthetics, contemporary Chinese ink paintings to the \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdpost-human\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Internet dimension.<br><br>To gain access to the journal follow the link below<br>http://bit.ly/1CZJeqv<br><br>Articles include (partial list):<br><br>Badiou in China?: Re-translations of French Maoism and inaesthetics<br>pp. 141-156(16)<br>Author: Wright, Colin<br>Alan Badiou\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds philosophy of art and his engagements with Maoism in order to speculate about the impact of that philosophy on contemporary Chinese art and critics. Opium and the Empire; Management in China </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BACS;731f19e6.1503</link>   <description> Transformations in Today's China<br><br>This course will focus upon the social, political and economic transformations that have taken place in China in the last three decades. In addition to providing a historical overview and factual information, the course aims to promote critical understanding of Chinese events and social structures. An important feature of the course is to encourage students to develop an understanding of interdisciplinary research and its potential through a multi-disciplinary teaching covering sociology, politics and economics.
